title: Excavating hidden data
body:
Open data is not just datasets available to download. In fact, this type of data represents only a small fraction of the available resources on the web.

There is also a huge amount of data available which at first appears hidden. A lot of data has been only designed for machines to read. In this module we look at techniques to unlock this hidden data.

In this module we’ll look at:
  • How to understand and identify hidden data
  • What benefits hidden data can provid
  • How to get hold of hidden data

title: Excavating hidden data – in two minutes
displayTitle: Excavating hidden data – in two minutes
body: The ODI’s David Tarrant explains why downloadable data represents just a fraction of the available resources on the web, the benefits of hidden, machine-readable data and how you as a user can get hold of these resources

title: Tip of the iceberg: the data people can't see
displayTitle: Tip of the iceberg: the data people can't see
body:
Open data is not always easy to find. For people navigating the web, we like to see visually-attractive websites, clicking through links and downloading files.

However the way we as people interact with the web is very different from the way a machine interacts with it. Machines navigate the web according to clearly defined rules and without any regard for the look and feel of the site. Therefore while humans may like engaging, interactive content, machines look for structure, logic and clarity.

This difference in the way people and machines read the web creates ‘blind-spots’ for both sides. Machines find it very difficult to pick out a downloadable files from a visual website. Similarly, we find it very difficult to get access to the structured, non-visual information obvious to a machine.

Our blind spot means what we can find and download is just the tip of the data iceberg. Much more data remains hidden from our eyes and we need to use machines to extract it from the web.

title: Finding hidden data
body: Not all data is available for download. Often it is hidden in the different websites we visit every day
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Why hide data?
_items.body:
Most of the time data is not intentionally hidden. A lot of the time it is not intentionally exposed.

The shift towards “Web 2.0”, the data driven mobile enabled web, has led to a different way of building web sites. These dynamic sites separate content from the look and feel. The expectation to build such sites has had the pleasant consequence of in many cases, exposing raw data that can be tapped into.

In some cases this exposing of data has led to the development of official channels of access, which starts to reveal what was previously hidden.

_items.title: Data is hiding everywhere
_items.body:
From wikipedia pages to holiday planners, fashion websites to energy providers, the web is full of rich sources of data.

Some of this data will be openly licensed, some will be licensed for personal use and the rest is likely to be very unclear in what you are explicitly permitted to use it for.

_items.title: What type of data is hiding?
_items.body:
You will need to be aware that the type of data that is hiding will be significantly different from that available for simple download.

While downloads are available in Excel and CSV formats, the machine readable data in the web will be in formats like JSON (the most common and simple to use), XML and sometimes RDF.

Try the exercises later in this module to see if you can extract data in these formats.

_items.title: Quality
_items.body:
In a lot of cases the “hidden” data will be what is used by the provider to render the web page you are looking at on their site.

Thus this data is a critical part of their operation. This instantly increases the quality of the data.

Additionally data extracted from the web tends to be more sustainable because, as we learned in module 7, data that is at the core of an organization's other activities is more likely to be a dependable source for the future.

_items.title: Relevance
_items.body: Drawing data directly from the web often means you can pinpoint a more relevant source than with downloads. Often organizations will not release downloadable data about a specific subject because they have either not found the time or do not have the incentive. However, by taking data directly from the web you have the ability to identify the most relevant resources regardless of their format and extract the relevant data.

_items.title: Context
_items.body:
When you access data directly from the web you are already viewing it in the context it is currently used by the provider. As we learned in the previous modules, the context of the data is an important component of its use.

By going directly from the web presence, you can understand how and for what purpose the organization currently uses the data.

_items.title: Redundant data
_items.body: Often an organization is limited in the amount of data it can publish as downloads. For this reason it is unlikely that all of the data opened by that company will be available in this format. By extracting hidden data, you open up a much broader range of resources.

title: Getting your hands on hidden data
displayTitle: Getting your hands on hidden data
body: Without data, we can’t build information.  And without information, there is no new knowledge
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Extension downloads
_items.body:
Some websites have been built with the ability to extract data simply by adding an extension to the address of the page you are on. For such websites, usually open data sites, adding the correct extension will trigger a download of that page in a data format as opposed to a browser format.

A good example of this is the UK government website.(gov.uk) which provides any page in a data format simply by adding the relevant extension like “.json”

Try it with the UK Trade data by viewing the following page and then adding “.json” to get the data.
Take me to the UK gov trade tariff

To view the data in a more human readable form copy it into jsonlint.io

_items.title: Data feeds
_items.body:
Many websites provide you with links to data syndication feeds that can you can subscribe to.

These feeds may be as simple as RSS feeds that provide you with blog entries or more advanced ones that can provide you alerts for flooding via twitter.


Why not try out the news feeds from the BBC

(note that the feeds are not web pages and will look different in every browser.
Why not look at the data in codebeautify

or get alerts for flooding from your nearest river (UK only):
Take me to river level guages

_items.title: Source code
_items.body:
Going beyond those websites that provide you with a simple route to the data many will have the data embedded in the pages source code.

This means that you can get access to the data by inspecting the pages code using your browser's ‘element inspector’.

,p>This slightly more advanced technique is not covered in this module but we hope to add a guide or tool to help in the future.

_items.title: APIs or machine-readable interfaces
_items.body:
Some websites or services will expose a machine readable interface, or API, for querying and accessing anything from a broad range of data to a single data point.

Some good examples of services that have such APIs include: Open Corporates (open), Open Steet Map (Open), Twitter (not completely open), Flickr (some content open), LinkedIn (not open).

Most of these services use a web based API and allow addition of extensions (try “.json” on OpenCorporates). Although this API looks like the first example in this section, the formalisation of it being an API provides a guarantee that the service will be available.

_items.title: Scraping the web
_items.body:
If none of the above techniques work then you may have to resort to scraping the human readable web pages. While this can be reliable you have the added risk of the layout changing as well as the content.

Why not try out magic.import.io to see how easy it can be?

title: Are you ready to find hidden data?
displayTitle: Are you ready to find hidden data?
body: Can you recall the key things about hidden data?

_items.text: Data visible to machines but invisible to human eyes?
Files that are difficult to download?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Hidden data is data that is invisible to people as they navigate the web but which a machine can easily find and understand

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Hidden data is data that is invisible to people as they navigate the web but which a machine can easily find and understand

title: Benefits of hidden data
body: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of hidden data?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Hidden data can increase the relevance and quality of the data, the breadth available and highlight the context in which the data is used.

_incorrect.notFinal: Hidden data can increase the relevance and quality of the data, the breadth available and highlight the context in which the data is used.
_incorrect.final: Hidden data can increase the relevance and quality of the data, the breadth available and highlight the context in which the data is used.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Hidden data can increase the relevance and quality of the data, the breadth available and highlight the context in which the data is used.
_partlyCorrect.final: Hidden data can increase the relevance and quality of the data, the breadth available and highlight the context in which the data is used.

title: How might you extract hidden data form a website?
displayTitle: How might you extract hidden data form a website?
body: Which of the following is a useful way to extract hidden data from the website?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Inspecting the source code of a website often reveals hidden data embedded in the page

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Inspecting the source code of a website often reveals hidden data embedded in the page

Hidden data can increase the relevance and quality of the data, the breadth available and highlight the context in which the data is used.

_partlyCorrect.final:

title: Compare. Measure. Success
body:
The data available for download is only a small fraction of what is available on the web.

While the human eye cannot always see this data, using machines it is possible to identify and grab a wealth of new data for your use.

The data excavated from these websites is often much broader and more relevant to your work that downloadable files and also draws directly from the context in which the organization is already using it

By raising your awareness of hidden data and learning some of the simple approaches in this module such as extension queries and source code inspection, you will be able to access a broad range of relevant open data for your future work.
